definition.text: Signals sent across the Superalgos peer to peer network are designed to be extensible and resource wise.

paragraphs.text: Now that we know a little bit about what signals can do, letâ€™s discuss some of the basic architecture of where trading signals live.  Because signals can hold a large amount of data, the entirety of a signal is not sent via the Superalgos peer to peer network.  Instead, signal providers send a header message via the peer to peer network that contains the address to the contents of the signal.  Breaking this architecture down looks like this:
Signal is split up into header and contents.
Contents are uploaded to an open access storage (currently this is a public github repository).
Header is sent via the peer to peer network to all subscribed signal recipients.
Signal recipients interpret the address of the signal and then download the signal contents.
This signal architecture greatly reduces the load on the Superalgos network allowing the transmission of large amounts of data to many recipients while using minimal network resources.
